@amber_jane_9 The way it was explained to me was that it defuses fights.

When individuals debate hot button issues in the second person ex. “you are hurting people!”, debate can devolve quickly as opposed to being forced to say “my colleague’s assertion of X is insulting to Y community”

At the moment, Medicare is banned from negotiating with big drug corporations to lower drug prices for every American. 

We want to lift that ban and give Medicare the power to negotiate for lower prices that we deserve. #LowerDrugCosts http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ELl_ujZXkAAo47e.jpg

The House has a full staff of parliamentarians to help members with all of this. It’s a very important job!

Another rule is that members aren’t really allowed to speak in the 2nd person on the House floor/ in committee.

That is why people who aren’t friends say “my good friend”

@PreetBharara This phrase is spoken during markups, which are different from hearings. In markups, members are debating the actual written substance of legislation - be it a bill, or (in this case) articles.

“Strike the last word” means you’re adding a pro forma amendment & using it to talk.

This phrase is spoken during markups, which are different from hearings. In markups, members are debating the actual written substance of legislation - be it a bill, or (in this case) articles.

“Strike the last word” means you’re adding a pro forma amendment & using it to talk.
